statement: F. Shovels Shoptime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputThere are $$$n$$$ shovels in the nearby shop. The $$$i$$$-th shovel costs $$$a_i$$$ bourles.Misha has to buyexactly$$$k$$$ shovels. Each shovel can be boughtno more than once.Misha can buy shovels by several purchases. During one purchase he can choose any subset of remaining (non-bought) shovels and buy this subset.There are also $$$m$$$ special offers in the shop. The $$$j$$$-th of them is given as a pair $$$(x_j, y_j)$$$, and it means that if Misha buysexactly$$$x_j$$$ shovelsduring one purchasethen $$$y_j$$$most cheapestof them are for free (i.e. he will not pay for $$$y_j$$$ most cheapest shovels during the current purchase).Misha can use any offer any (possibly, zero) number of times, but he cannot usemore than oneoffer duringone purchase(but he can buy shovels without using any offers).Your task is to calculate the minimum cost of buying $$$k$$$ shovels, if Misha buys them optimally.InputThe first line of the input contains three integers $$$n, m$$$ and $$$k$$$ ($$$1 \\le n, m \\le 2 \\cdot 10^5, 1 \\le k \\le min(n, 2000)$$$) — the number of shovels in the shop, the number of special offers and the number of shovels Misha has to buy, correspondingly.The second line of the input contains $$$n$$$ integers $$$a_1, a_2, \\dots, a_n$$$ ($$$1 \\le a_i \\le 2 \\cdot 10^5$$$), where $$$a_i$$$ is the cost of the $$$i$$$-th shovel.The next $$$m$$$ lines contain special offers. The $$$j$$$-th of them is given as a pair of integers $$$(x_i, y_i)$$$ ($$$1 \\le y_i \\le x_i \\le n$$$) and means that if Misha buys exactly $$$x_i$$$ shovels during some purchase, then he can take $$$y_i$$$ most cheapest of them for free.OutputPrint one integer — the minimum cost of buying $$$k$$$ shovels if Misha buys them optimally.ExamplesInput7 4 5 2 5 4 2 6 3 1 2 1 6 5 2 1 3 1Output7Input9 4 8 6 8 5 1 8 1 1 2 1 9 2 8 4 5 3 9 7Output17Input5 1 4 2 5 7 4 6 5 4Output17NoteIn the first example Misha can buy shovels on positions $$$1$$$ and $$$4$$$ (both with costs $$$2$$$) during the first purchase and get one of them for free using the first or the third special offer. And then he can buy shovels on positions $$$3$$$ and $$$6$$$ (with costs $$$4$$$ and $$$3$$$) during the second purchase and get the second one for free using the first or the third special offer. Then he can buy the shovel on a position $$$7$$$ with cost $$$1$$$. So the total cost is $$$4 + 2 + 1 = 7$$$.In the second example Misha can buy shovels on positions $$$1$$$, $$$2$$$, $$$3$$$, $$$4$$$ and $$$8$$$ (costs are $$$6$$$, $$$8$$$, $$$5$$$, $$$1$$$ and $$$2$$$) and get three cheapest (with costs $$$5$$$, $$$1$$$ and $$$2$$$) for free. And then he can buy shovels on positions $$$6$$$, $$$7$$$ and $$$9$$$ (all with costs $$$1$$$) without using any special offers. So the total cost is $$$6 + 8 + 1 + 1 + 1 = 17$$$.In the third example Misha can buy four cheapest shovels without using any special offers and get the total cost $$$17$$$.

There are $n$ shovels for sale, with the $i$-th shovel costing $a_i$ bourles. You need to buy exactly $k$ shovels.

You can buy shovels in multiple purchases. In each purchase, you can choose any set of unbought shovels.

There are $m$ special offers. The $j$-th offer states that if you buy exactly $x_j$ shovels in a single purchase, then the $y_j$ cheapest shovels in that purchase are free.

You can use each offer any number of times, but only one offer per purchase. You cannot use an offer and buy shovels without using an offer in the same purchase.

Find the minimum total cost to buy $k$ shovels, using the offers optimally.

You have a set of items with different prices. You need to buy a specific number of items. There are also special offers where buying a certain number of items lets you get some of the cheapest items for free. Find the cheapest way to buy the required number of items, considering the special offers.
